NOTE_ID: note_069
SOURCE_FILE: note_069.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 54-year-old female who presents with extrinsic compression and endobronchial tumor invasion.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RUL bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Extensive partially obstructing vascular endobronchial tumor and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RUL orifice.
RUL: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RUL. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB1 (apical) was confirmed; RB2 (posterior) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RUL (RB1, RB2, and RB3) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Boston Scientific Ultraflex 10x40mm cover stent was placed in the RUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB1, RB2, and RB3 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RUL Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 54-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RUL.
Stent: Placement of Boston Scientific Ultraflex 10x40mm cover stent in RUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Fleshy, polypoid endobronchial mass and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x15mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 67-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x15mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the LUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the LUL (LB3, LB4, and LB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent was placed in the LUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both LB3, LB4, and LB5 segments.

Left Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Left Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. LUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
LUL Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and LUL.

Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 59-year-old male who presents with extrinsic compression and endobronchial tumor invasion.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RUL bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Fleshy, polypoid endobronchial mass and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RUL orifice.
RUL: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RUL. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB1 (apical) was confirmed; RB2 (posterior) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RUL (RB1, RB2, and RB3) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Boston Scientific Ultraflex 10x40mm cover stent was placed in the RUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB1, RB2, and RB3 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RUL Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 59-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RUL.
Stent: Placement of Boston Scientific Ultraflex 10x40mm cover stent in RUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Fleshy, polypoid endobronchial mass and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 0% patent to 75% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 67-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and LUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Left Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the LUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of LB3 (apical-posterior) was confirmed; LB4 (lingular) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the LUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the LUL (LB3, LB4, and LB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x15mm stent was placed in the LUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both LB3, LB4, and LB5 segments.

Left Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Left Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. LUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
LUL Bronchus: Improved from 1% patent to 80% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 54-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and LUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and LUL.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x15mm stent in LUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 61-year-old male who presents with bronchial stenosis related to endobronchial tumor.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RUL bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Infiltrating submucosal tumor with exophytic component and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RUL orifice.
RUL: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RUL. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB1 (apical) was confirmed; RB2 (posterior) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RUL (RB1, RB2, and RB3) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x10mm stent was placed in the RUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB1, RB2, and RB3 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RUL Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RUL.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x10mm stent in RUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Left Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - LUL bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Friable, necrotic tumor with white debris and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and LUL orifice.
LUL: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Left Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and LUL. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and LUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Left Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the LUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of LB3 (apical-posterior) was confirmed; LB4 (lingular) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the LUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the LUL (LB3, LB4, and LB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Boston Scientific Ultraflex 10x40mm cover stent was placed in the LUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both LB3, LB4, and LB5 segments.

Left Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Left Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. LUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
LUL Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
LUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 67-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and LUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and LUL.
Stent: Placement of Boston Scientific Ultraflex 10x40mm cover stent in LUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

Trachea/Bronchi: Fleshy, polypoid endobronchial mass and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x15mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 1% patent to 80% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 64-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x15mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 67-year-old female who presents with respiratory failure secondary to central airway obstruction.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RML bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Friable, necrotic tumor with white debris and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x15mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 1% patent to 80% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 67-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x15mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 72-year-old female who presents with respiratory failure secondary to central airway obstruction.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RML bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Extensive partially obstructing vascular endobronchial tumor and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x10mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 72-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x10mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Extensive partially obstructing vascular endobronchial tumor and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x15mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 72-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x15mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

Trachea/Bronchi: Infiltrating submucosal tumor with exophytic component and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RML orifice.
RML: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 5% patent to 90% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 54-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION: The patient is a 64-year-old male who presents with respiratory failure secondary to central airway obstruction.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.

CONSENT: Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient. Informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RUL bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Fleshy, polypoid endobronchial mass and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RUL orifice.
RUL: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RUL. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB1 (apical) was confirmed; RB2 (posterior) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RUL (RB1, RB2, and RB3) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent was placed in the RUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB1, RB2, and RB3 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RUL Bronchus: Improved from 1% patent to 80% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 64-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RUL.
Stent: Placement of Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent in RUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31625 Endobronchial Biopsy(s)
31630 Balloon dilation - Right Lower Lobe bronchus (no stent placed)
31636 Dilate and bronchial stent initial bronchus - RUL bronchus (dilation and stent placement)
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING: Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION: Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Flexible Hybrid (Pediatric) Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal

COMPLICATIONS: None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location). Sedation was initiated and an LMA was placed.

Initial Airway Inspection: The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords, main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Larynx/Vocal Cords: No lesions; normal movement without mass.

Trachea/Bronchi: Friable, necrotic tumor with white debris and overlying white necrotic debris were noted involving the mid-trachea, distal trachea, main carina, and lobar bronchi.

Severity: Obstruction was most severe at the distal trachea and RUL orifice.
RUL: Highly stenotic and completely obstructed by tumor, debris, and mucus; unable to traverse initially.
Right Lower Lobe: Moderate stenosis due to tumor and extrinsic compression.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RUL. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RUL was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Upper Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RUL bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB1 (apical) was confirmed; RB2 (posterior) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RUL stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RUL (RB1, RB2, and RB3) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An AEROMini 6x10mm stent was placed in the RUL bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB1, RB2, and RB3 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RUL): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RUL Bronchus: Improved from 1% patent to 80% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RUL BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 54-year-old female who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RUL stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RUL.
Stent: Placement of AEROMini 6x10mm stent in RUL bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.

Therapeutic Interventions

Therapeutic Aspiration: Secretions were moderate, thin, and clear. Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clear mucus and overlying necrotic debris from the trachea and mainstem bronchi.

Endobronchial Biopsy: Biopsies were performed at tumor sites in the trachea, main carina, and RML. These were combined into a single sample labeled "trachea".

Tumor Excision: The obstructing tumor at the trachea, main carina, and RML was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.

Tumor Ablation (APC): Tumor destruction was performed using a 1.5mm Pulmonary axial 'straight-fire' probe (forcedAPC, 0.5 LPM, Max Watts 30-40) in 1-5 second bursts. Extensive tumor ablation and hemostasis were achieved.

Right Middle Lobe Management:
After tumor excision and ablation, the RML bronchus was traversed with a Hybrid bronchoscope and saline hydrodissection. Patency of RB4 (lateral) was confirmed; RB5 (medial) appeared viable but filled with debris.

Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the RML stenosis to 7 mm (2 inflations, 60 and 30 seconds). The therapeutic scope could then traverse with moderate pressure.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at the RML (RB4 and RB5) with 60 cc instilled and 15 cc returned.

Stent Placement: An Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent was placed in the RML bronchus. It seated very well and maintained patency of both RB4 and RB5 segments.

Right Lower Lobe Management:
Balloon Dilation: A 6/7/8 mm Elation balloon was used to dilate the Right Lower Lobe bronchus take-off to 8 mm (1 inflation, 60 seconds).

Results and Patency
Trachea: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.
Right-sided airways (excl. RML): Improved from 60% patent to 90% patent.
RML Bronchus: Improved from 10% patent to 85% patent.
Left Mainstem: Improved from 80% patent to 95% patent.

Residual secretions, saline, and blood were suctioned to clear. The patient tolerated the procedure well. The LMA was removed in the operating room.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsy (combined samples): Pathology
RML BAL: Cell count, micro/cultures, cytology

IMPRESSION/PLAN
The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent bronchoscopy for endobronchial tumor excision/ablation, airway dilation, and RML stent placement.

Intervention: Extensive endobronchial tumor excision and ablation in the trachea and RML.
Stent: Placement of Merit Endotek 8x20mm stent in RML bronchus.

Post-Procedure Care:
Follow-up post-op CXR.
Await EBBx and BAL results.
Stent hydration/hygiene protocol: QID albuterol nebulizer, hypertonic saline (3%, 4mL) nebulizer, and flutter valve regimen; Mucinex 1200mg BID for mucolysis.
Engage case management to obtain devices/meds prior to discharge.

Follow-up: Repeat bronchoscopy with airway evaluation, stent check, and likely additional tumor excision/ablation in ~3-4 weeks. Consideration of rigid bronchoscopy with micro-debrider given extensive involvement.
